IMAGE-HIGH-RES CHNJC 64182 S1872-2067(22)64182-2 10.1016/S1872-2067(22)64182-2 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Editorial Preface to the special issue on electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis Prof. Yanguang Li Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials, Soochow University Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials Soochow University Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials, Soochow University Prof. Yujie Sun Department of Chemistry, University of Cincinnati Department of Chemistry University of Cincinnati Department of Chemistry, University of Cincinnati Graphical Abstract Electrochemistry is an important branch of modern chemistry that studies the relationship between electrical energy and chemistry changes. Two actively pursued directions within this discipline are electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis, which are closely connected with different focuses and targets. The former is involved in many energy conversion technologies including fuel cells, water electrolyzers and metal-air batteries, while the latter enables the selective production of organic chemicals in a controlled fashion under mild conditions. Both electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis often rely on the use of electrocatalysts (either homogeneous or heterogeneous) in order to accelerate the reaction rate, promote the reaction selectivity and improve the energy efficiency. As a result, the development of efficient and robust electrocatalyst materials via varying engineering strategies is at the very heart. There are also ongoing endeavors to study the complex reality of catalyst surface, electrode and electrolyte, and to understand the reaction pathway and mechanism. Over the last decade, there is a dramatic surge of research interest on electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis within China and around the world as evidenced by the increasing amount of publications every year. We, as both authors and editors, feel compelled to organize a special issue on this topic for disseminating latest results and overviewing recent advances. This special contains 20 papers from rising young scholars working in the frontier of electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis, and includes 1 perspective, 6 reviews, 3 communications and 10 articles. It covers the broad topics of hydrogen electrocatalysis, oxygen electrocatalysis, CO2 reduction, N2 reduction, biomass upgrading and electrocarboxylation. We would like to thanks all the authors for their great contributions, and hope the readers would find our collection useful and interesting.
